data.title: amastro@groups.io
data.text:
Michael Kerr

Does anyone know who discovered the dwarf irregular galaxy Sextans B (= DDO

75, UGC 5373)? I've searched NED, ADS and the web without success.

Mike

Regards,

Mike

Brian Skiff

The RC1 notes (given in NED) cite only Zwicky's 1957 monograph,

"Morphological Astronomy", which I presume is the source of the

discovery.

The on-line bibliographic databases aren't complete before

about 1980, so will often not give you a ready link to information

like this.

\Brian

Steinicke-Streifeneder@t-online.de

Hello Michael,

MK> Does anyone know who discovered the dwarf irregular galaxy Sextans B (= DDO

MK> 75, UGC 5373)? I've searched NED, ADS and the web without success.

Sextans B was discovered around 1952 by Albert G. Wilson at Palomar.

He was also the discoverer of some other interesting dwarfs (found during

the making of the POSS), e.g. Sextans C, Draco dwarf, and (with

Harrington) Leo I + II.

Informations about "Al" Wilson can be found here:

www.lowell.edu/Research/library/paper/al_wilson.html

Cheers,

Wolfgang

Michael Kerr

Brian and Wolfgang,

Thanks for the leads on the discoverer of Sextans B (= DDO 70, UGC 5373).

I followed up your suggestions at the AAO library and can confirm that the

first documented report of Sextans B appears to be in F. Zwicky's 1957 book

"Morphological Astronomy". Zwicky includes Sextans B in a table of dwarf

galaxies discovered with the 48-inch Schmidt telescope (Table XLVIII, p.

225) and a footnote to the table says that "A. G. Wilson who discovered

most of them..." Wilson himself doesn't seem to have published anything on

the discovery. He left Palomar-Mt Wilson in 1953 so Wolfgang's date of

"around 1952" seems reasonable.

I am a bit surprised that Wilson's 1955 paper "Sculptor-Type Systems in the

Local Group of Galaxies" (1955PASP...67...27W), which lists the known

Sculptor-type galaxies, doesn't include Sextans A (discovered by Zwicky

around 1939/40, = DDO 75, MCG -01-26-030) or Sextans B. This paper also

reports Wilson's discovery of the Sextans globular cluster (Sextans C,

Palomar 3), which he notes was independently discovered by Walter Baade.

Mike

Steinicke-Streifeneder@t-online.de

Hello Michael,

MK> Wilson himself doesn't seem to have published anything on

MK> the discovery.

Maybe it is published in the yearbook of the Palomar Observaory for

1952/53. The first note ("Wilson's dwarf in Sextans") can be found in

the table of E. Petitt's paper ApJ 120, 413 (1954).

Wilson found many "Palomar globulars" (some are rediscoveries) on

Schmidt-plates. He must be credited for Pal 2 (1950) and Pal 3 (1952,

together with Baade), the "10h cluster" in Sextans. Maybe this was the

time of the Sextans B discovery. Further Pal 10 + 11 (1955) and Pal 13

(1953). He rediscovered Hubbles "11h cluster" (Pal 4) on a

Schmidt-Platte of 1950, also Baades's Pal 5 in 1955. Wilson also found

26 peculiar galaxies, included in Arp's Atlas.

Wolfgang

Michael Kerr

Hi Wolfgang,

Maybe it is published in the yearbook of the Palomar Observaory for

1952/53. The first note ("Wilson's dwarf in Sextans") can be found in

the table of E. Petitt's paper ApJ 120, 413 (1954).

Thanks for pointing out the Pettit paper. I'm impressed that you picked up

the reference to the "Wilson Dwarf Irr" in the table. Based on this there

seems little doubt that Wilson discovered Sextans B. I checked the "Annual

Report of the Director of the Mount Wilson Observatory" for the years 1950

to 1958 when I was at the library today but couldn't find any mention of

the discovery.

Mike
